rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:1
rsbNotes.text: 29:1 Hezekiah. The reign of Hezekiah (716–687 b.c.) begins a new era in the history of Israel and Judah. The northern kingdom had been destroyed by the Assyrians and only Judah remained. Hezekiah brought together representatives from both kingdoms to form a single, reunited kingdom with one king and one temple in Jerusalem. The writer of Chronicles devotes more attention to Hezekiah than any other king except David and Solomon. He uses material from 2 Kin. 18–20, but he supplements it broadly, including an extensive account of Hezekiah’s temple reforms and Passover celebration (29:3–31:1). Hezekiah’s reign appears as a return to the glory of Solomon’s kingdom.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:3
rsbNotes.text: 29:3 opened the doors . . . and repaired them. Hezekiah overturns the actions of his father Ahaz (28:25 note) and restores the gold ornamentation stripped from the temple doors (2 Kin. 16:8, 9).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:4
rsbNotes.text: 29:4 Chronicles normally gives attention to matters concerning the priests and Levites (1 Chr. 6:1 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:4–11
rsbNotes.text: 29:4–11 Hezekiah’s speech stands in contrast with Abijah’s earlier assessments (13:6–12 notes). Judah is no longer different from Israel; both have forsaken God. Judah must repent as well.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:7
rsbNotes.text: 29:7 shut the doors. As Ahaz did (28:24).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:8
rsbNotes.text: 29:8 on Judah and Jerusalem. Hezekiah asserts that Judah and Jerusalem were under the curse of God for their neglect of the temple.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:9
rsbNotes.text: 29:9 in captivity. During the reign of Ahaz, many people from Judah were taken into exile by the Syrians (28:5–8) and Edomites (28:17). These events foreshadowed the Babylonian captivity to come (36:15–23), making the reign of Hezekiah a persuasive example for restoration after exile.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:10
rsbNotes.text:
29:10 in my heart. The anger of God turned Hezekiah toward Him in repentance, not away from Him in fear.

make a covenant. See note 15:12.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:12–14
rsbNotes.text: 29:12–14 The historian mentions representatives of the three divisions of the tribe of Levi (v. 12) and the three families of singers (vv. 13, 14). Hezekiah’s reforms were widely supported by the Levites and in accordance with the order established under David and Solomon (1 Chr. 6:1 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:13
rsbNotes.text: 29:13 Elizaphan. A prominent leader of the Kohathites (Num. 3:30).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:16
rsbNotes.text: 29:16 priests went into the inner part. The historian offers these details to demonstrate that Hezekiah’s renovation strictly accorded with Mosaic legislation.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:20–36
rsbNotes.text: 29:20–36 Hezekiah’s dedication of the temple is reported in three parts: sacrifices brought by the leaders (vv. 20–24), arrangement of music (vv. 25–30), and sacrifices brought by the people (vv. 31–36).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:21
rsbNotes.text: 29:21 for the kingdom . . . sanctuary . . . Judah. Sacrifices were made on behalf of the royal family, the priests and Levites, and the people. All three groups were involved in the apostasy under Ahaz (2 Kin. 16).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:24
rsbNotes.text: 29:24 all Israel. In connection with the reunited kingdom (chs. 29–36), the expression “all Israel” (30:1; 31:1; 35:3) refers to both Judah together with the refugees from the northern tribes (1 Chr. 11:1 note; 2 Chr. 10:1 note). Hezekiah ordered sacrifices to be offered, not for Judah only (v. 21), but for all the descendants of Israel. This desire to unite is clearly expressed in his arrangements for the Passover (30:1–6).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:25
rsbNotes.text: 29:25 cymbals, harps, and lyres. See note 1 Chr. 15:16.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:32–35
rsbNotes.text: 29:32–35 These sacrifices were fewer in number, but still a reminder of what Solomon had offered when the temple was dedicated (7:4–6).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 29:36
rsbNotes.text: 29:36 came about suddenly. The restoration of the temple took less than three weeks (vv. 3, 17), an evidence that God was working in the people.
